item.title: jyotirmaTha lineage
item.description:
The Jyotirmaṭha Śaṅkarācārya Lineage in the 20th Century
Vidyāśaṅkar Sundareśan

This page was first born in response to the INDOLOGY listserv discussion (January 19, 1998) about the [Śaṅkarācārya of the North], and has been updated a few times since then. Barring fresh developments in future, this version (July 2000) will be final.

There is currently a succession dispute at the Jyotirmaṭha Śaṅkarācārya seat, the origin of which dates back to the year 1953. Till recently, the two major rivals were Svāmī Svarūpānanda Sarasvatī (who is also the Śaṅkarācārya of Dvārakā in the west) and Svāmī Vāsudevānanda Sarasvatī. Since 1993-4, another Saṃnyāsin named Mādhava Āśrama has been a third claimant to the Jyotirmaṭha title.

item.title: kAnchI-maTha-history 94
item.description:
Subject: Real history of the Kanchi math (Re: Former President Inaugurates…) Celebrations
From: vidya@cco.caltech.edu (Vidyasankar Sundaresan)
Date: 3 Aug 1994 04:05:16 GMT

Both this post and a previous one by Bon Giovanni have raised questions of historicity of Adi Sankaracharya and the Kanchi math. This is not a new question. It is generally accepted as tradition that Adi Sankaracharya, the famous Advaita philosopher, founded four maths (monasteries) at Sringeri, Puri, Dwaraka and Badrinath; that he ascended the famous sarvagna-pitha in Kashmir, and finally passed away near Kedarnath. None of the four recognized mathas claims jurisdiction over the other three. However, the Kanchi math claims that Sankaracharya established a fifth math in Kanchi, with jurisdiction over the recognized four mathas; that Sankaracharya ascended a sarvagna-pitha not in Kashmir, but at Kanchi, and that he passed away not in Kedarnath, but at Kanchi. These and other such claims have been widely publicized by the followers of the Kanchi math with the direct participation of and encouragement from the heads of the Kanchi math, including the recently departed centenarian Sri Chandrasekharendra Saraswati (C.S., for short) and his successor Sri Jayendra Saraswati (J.S.).

item.title: Shaṅkaravijaya History
item.description:
Conflicting hagiographies and history: The place of Śaṅkaravijaya texts in Advaita tradition
Vidyasankar Sundaresan

Gemini summary - dates

Based on the provided text, here is a table of the determined date ranges for the various texts considered:

Text Author/Attribution Determined Date/Range
Śaṅkara’s undisputed works Śaṅkarācārya Early 8th Century CE
Madhavīya Śaṅkaravijaya (or Samksepa Śaṅkarajaya) Traditionally Vidyāraṇya Composed before 1783 CE, with traditional attribution placing it in the 14th Century CE.
Anantānandagiri’s Śaṅkaravijaya Anantānandagiri Post-14th Century CE
Cidvilāsa’s Śaṅkaravijaya Vilāsa Cidvilāsa Possibly 17th Century CE or later
Sadānanda’s Śaṅkaravijaya Sāra Sadānanda 1783 CE
Rājacūḍāmaṇi dīkṣita’s Śaṅkarābhyudaya Rājacūḍāmaṇi dīkṣita 17th Century CE
Govindanātha’s Śaṅkarācāryacarita (Keralīya Śaṅkaravijaya) Govindanātha Usually dated to the 17th Century CE
Br̥hat Śaṅkaravijaya Attributed to Citsukha Existence is uncertain; Citsukha is identified as a 13th-century author.
Prācīna Śaṅkaravijaya Attributed to Anandagiri Existence is uncertain; Anandagiri, the commentator, lived in the 13th Century CE.
Naiṣadhīyacarita Śrīharṣa 12th Century CE
Vyāsācala’s Śaṅkaravijaya Vyāsācala One scholar dates it to the 15th Century CE.
Tirumala Dīkṣita’s Śaṅkarābhyudaya Tirumala Dīkṣita Around 1700 CE
Rāmabhadra Dīkṣita’s Patañjalicarita Rāmabhadra dīkṣita 17th Century CE
Vedāntakalpataru Amalānanda Early 13th Century CE
Ḍiṇḍima (Commentary on Mādhavīya) Dhanapatisūrin Completed in 1798 CE
Advaitarājyalakṣmi (Commentary on Mādhavīya) Acyutarāya 1824 CE
Śrī Gurucaritra Gangādhara Sarasvatī 15th Century CE Marathi text
Nilakantha’s works, Hosinga Vāsudeva dīkṣita’s work, Lakṣmaṇasūrin’s work Various Described as being “about a century old” at the time the paper was written.
